# Identifying outliers

- How do we **.darkorange[identify outliers]**?

--
  
  - Visual inspection (e.g. plots, tables)
  
  - Creating thresholds (e.g. z-scores, IQ)
  
--

- There is **.darkorange[no definite way to identify outliers]**

  - Like the characterization of pornography, "I know it when I see it" (P. Stewart, 1964)

---
background-position: 50% 50%
class: center, middle

.box-3LA[Let's go to R]

---
# What to do with outliers?

1. **.darkorange[Check them!]**

  - Make sure there's no coding error; try to understand what's happening there.

--

2a. **.darkorange[If they are wrongly coded]**:

  - You can remove them, always adding a note of why you did so
  - Be aware of sample selection!
  
--
  
2b. **.darkorange[If they are correctly coded]**:

  - Run analysis both with and without outliers (don't just drop them!).
  - Robust results: Do not depend exclusively on a few observations.

# What's the problem with multicollinearity?

- What do you think would happen if I ran this regression?

$$Cancer = \beta_0 + \beta_1 Pack Cigarettes + \beta_2 NCigarettes + \varepsilon$$

--

- If two covariates are **.darkorange[perfectly collinear]**, we can't run the regression
  
  - R will drop one of them!
  
--

- But what happens when they are highly correlated but not *perfectly collinear*?

---

```{r}
housing <- housing %>% filter(Bldg.Type=="1Fam")

```

# How do number of rooms and living area relate to sale price?

--
```{r rooms_area, fig.height=5, fig.width=12, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
library(ggplot2)
library(firasans)
library(hrbrthemes)
library(hrbrthemes)
library(extrafont)
library(tidyverse)
library(vtable)
library(patchwork)



g1 <- ggplot(data = housing, aes(x = TotRms.AbvGrd, y = SalePrice)) +
  geom_point(color = "#F89441", fill = "white", pch=21, size = 2) + 
  theme_bw()+
  xlab("Total Number of Rooms") + ylab("Sale Price (US$)") +
  theme_ipsum_fsc(plot_title_face = "bold",plot_title_size = 24) + #plain 

  theme(plot.margin=unit(c(1,1,1.5,1.2),"cm"),
        panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank(),
        axis.line = element_line(colour = "dark grey"))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 10, r = 0, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size=14),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 0, r = 10, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.y = element_text(size=14),legend.position="none",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.text = element_text(size=15),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill="white",colour ="white"),
        title = element_text(size=14))

g2 <- ggplot(data = housing, aes(x = Gr.Liv.Area, y = SalePrice)) +
  geom_point(color = "#E16462", fill = "white", pch=21, size = 2) + 
  theme_bw()+
  xlab("Living Area (sq ft)") + ylab("Sale Price (US$)") +
  theme_ipsum_fsc(plot_title_face = "bold",plot_title_size = 24) + #plain 

  theme(plot.margin=unit(c(1,1,1.5,1.2),"cm"),
        panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank(),
        axis.line = element_line(colour = "dark grey"))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 10, r = 0, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size=14),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 0, r = 10, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.y = element_text(size=14),legend.position="none",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.text = element_text(size=15),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill="white",colour ="white"),
        title = element_text(size=14))

g1 + g2
```

```{r, eval=FALSE}
summary(lm_full)
```

]

- What can you say about **.darkorange[total rooms]**?

---
# Multicollinearity in Regressors

- If two covariates are **.darkorange[highly correlated]**, it is difficult to separate the contribution of each!

  - E.g. They move together

--

- **.darkorange[Be careful]** with interpretations

  - The same with extrapolation zones!
  
---
# Can we do something about it?

- **.darkorange[Exclude]** one variable

  - Depends on what you are analyzing.
  
--

- Create a **.darkorange[new variable]** that captures clean information

  - E.g. Residuals 

--

- **.darkorange[Aggregate]** both variables into one:

  - Linear combination (e.g. add them)
  
  - Create an index

---
# Takeaway points

.pull-left[

- Always make sure to **.darkorange[check your data]**:

  - What are analyzing? Does the data behave as I would expect? Should I exclude observations?
  
- Is it a problem if my covariates are **.darkorange[highly correlated]**?
  
  - Sometimes yes, sometimes no.
  
]
